Madurai Meenakshi Amman temple is a gem on the crown of the Nayak’s architectural brilliance is well known to the modern world but there lies many specific legends related to this specific temple than any other temples.

  • Meenakshi amman temple is dedicated to Meenakshi, an avatar of Goddess Parvati. Though there are many temples dedicated to the main female deity of Saivite sect of Hinduism, this is the place where the Goddess was born as a girl and married Shiva and people of Madurai still believes Meenakshi is ruling the Madurai city.

Madurai Meenakshi Amman temple is a gem on the crown of the Nayak’s architectural brilliance is well known to the modern world but there lies many specific legends related to this specific temple than any other temples.

  • Meenakshi amman temple is dedicated to Meenakshi, an avatar of Goddess Parvati. Though there are many temples dedicated to the main female deity of Saivite sect of Hinduism, this is the place where the Goddess was born as a girl and married Shiva and people of Madurai still believes Meenakshi is ruling the Madurai city.
  • Though being a Shiva temple, Meenakshi is given prime importance in this temple. Sundareswarar shrine do not lie at the intersection point of all the four main gopurams in the four direction. This implies that Shiva has given way to Meenakshi to gain importance.
  • Meenakshi is ruling Madurai from Chitrai to Aadi, the first four Tamil months and from Aavani to Panguni, and the last eight Tamil months is believed to be ruled by Sundareswarar(Shiva). This shows that women equality was given importance many centuries ago.
  • Every Hindu temple is dedicated to some legends of the Gods performing a divine act (திருவிளையாடல்). Meenakshi amman temple is the only temple where Shiva has performed his 64 divine acts. No other temple has such a significance.
  • Natarajar, the dancing form of Shiva, always have its right foot set on a dwarf and the left foot raised in air. Here in Meenakshi amman temple, one can witness a different form under the silver roof (வெள்ளி அம்பலம்). As per the legends, Rajasekara Pandyan after performing Bharatanatyam, felt how tireless to dance and worried about Shiva dancing on the same leg for centuries. To please his devotee, Shiva changed his foot and set the left foot on the dwarf and raised his right foot in the air. This form can only be seen in Madurai Meenakshi Amman temple.
  • Meenakshi amman’s statue was carved out of emerald. Its beauty is spell bound and attracted the Delhi sultanate raider Malik Kafur. Priests of the temple closed the garbhagraham of Meenakshi Amman and Sundareswarar with stone wall and a proxy idol was kept in front of it. Malik Kafur raided Meenakshi’s proxy idol and went to raid the Sundareswarar’s shrine. It is said that an ascetic appeared and claimed that the eight elephant sculptures present in the pillars would eat sugarcane if fed. Malik Kafur tested it and the stone elephant extended its trunk and ate the sugarcane and it is said that Malik Kafur stopped the raid and backed. After the decline of Sultanate dynasty in the South, almost 48 years, the garbhagaraham of Meenakshi and Sundareswarar were opened and to the surprise, the lamp lit before 48 years was still burning, sandal paste on the idol was damp and the garlands fresh.
  • Golden lotus pond (பொற்றாமரை குளம்) do not give life to any fish even in the present. This is related to one of the 64 divine acts performed by Shiva in Madurai. Once a stork, ate the fish in this pond and felt that it had committed a sin by eating the fish from the divine pond. It stood on a single leg for many days and attained salvation. Makesh Balasubramani's answer to What is the truth behind no fishes in the golden lotus pond at Meenakshi Temple? Recently in 2016, a similar event repeated by another stork standing in single leg for many days and finally died. Stork at Meenakshi temple tank that attracted devotees is dead | Madurai News - Times of India

As the popular belief of Madurai people, Madurai is ruled by both Meenakshi and Sundareswarar and the God can make his presence felt anytime in the temple even in the recent days. Meenakshi amman temple is not just a temple, it’s where the God expresses himself to the people even in the present days.

Madurai Meenakshi Amman temple is an ancient historic Hindu temple on the southern bank of the Vaigai River in the temple city of Madurai, Tamil Nadu, India. It is dedicated to Goddess Meenakshi and Sundareswarari.

Not only temple architectural brilliance, history of the temple, gopuram, mandapams and golden lotus in tank and each and every minute thins is mind blowing in Amman temple.In this 1,000-pillared hall, there is a temple art museum where you can examine artwork from 1200 years ago, including drawings, pictures, and icons.

In the temple, numerous other small and large mandapams exist. The Musical Pillars are located directly outside this mandapam, to the west.

When a pillar becomes stuck, it produces a unique musical note. On the Kalyana Mandapa, which is to the south of the pillared hall, the annual Chitirai Festival, which takes place in mid-April, honors the union of Shiva and Parvati.

Are there any Hindu temples built before the 7th century CE in Telugu states?

Yeah, we have ancient Hindu temples built before and around 7th century in both Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. The Architecture, sculpturing of these temples are quite amazing. Some of these temples are unknown to many of us. Let's check those temples.

Jogulamba Navabrahma Temple :

This picture was captured by me

Where is it situated? It's situated in Alampuram, Jogulamba Gadwal district/ Old Mahbubnagar district of Telangana, near the meeting point of rivers Krishna and Tungabhadra at the border of Andhra Pradesh. This site is also called as Dhakshina Kasi. Alampuram is land of temples.

Who built these temples? The Chalukyan kings had built these amazing temples. They followed their own Badami Chalukyan Architecture. But these temples were badly damaged and some razed to the ground during the Islamic invasion of this region.

Don’t think these temples are dedicated to Brahma, because Lord Shiva is the main deity of this 9 temples and called as Brahmeswara. Goddess Jogulamba is also worshiped here as one of the Shakthi Peetas.

What are the 9 temple’s Gods name? Tharaka Brahma, Swarga Brahma, Padma Brahma,Bala Brahma, Garuda Brahma, Arka Brahma, Kumara Brahma, Veera Brahma, Vishwa Brahma.

The sculptures of this temple depict Shaivism, Vaishnavism and Shakthism. Many mythological stories were depicted in the form of carvings and sculptures.

Ramappa Temple’s architecture was inspired from this temple’s architecture only.

Srikakulandhra Mahavishnuvu Temple:

Where is it located? It’s located in Krishna District of AP.

Who’s the main deity? Lord Mahavishnuvu

It is perhaps one of the oldest temples in South India.

When was it built? It could have been built in 2nd or 3 rd century BC. That means the temple is thousands of years old. The surprising part about the temple is that the Sanctorum has survived the way it was built all through these years.

The temple got its name from a story that took place in these parts. Maha Vishnuvu was a fearless warrior who ruled this small kingdom. During his reign people came to believe that he is an incarnation of Lord Vishnu himself. That is why the temple has been named as Andhra Vishnu temple.

Krishnadevaraya said

Andhra Viṣhṇu told him to compose the story of his wedding with Andal at Srirangam. He also ordered the emperor to tell the story in the Telugu language. The emperor obliged, compsing Amuktamalyada which is one of the most famous poetic works in Telugu literature. From 14th poem of this work we can see that the Lord Śrī Āndhra Viṣhṇu refers himself as King of Telugus (Telugu Vallabhunḍa) and refers Sri Krishnadevaraya as Kannada King (Kannaḍa Rāya).

Devunigutta Temple:

Where is this situated? It’s situated in Kothur Village of Jayashankar Bhupalapalli District/ Old Warangal District.

It is thought the temple was built about the 6th century CE under the Vishnukundina dynasty. It is in a "remote forested plateau",and only came to the attention of experts in 2012, when it was reported to the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) and local papers. However, it did not come to wider attention until images of it were posted on social media in 2017, after which a number of international scholars visited it, and published scholarly reports began to appear. It has an unusual profusion of relief sculptures, many very worn, both inside and outside.

The sculptures prominently include Shiva in the form of Ardhanariswara. The temple now consists of a square sanctuary with a Shikhara or Vimana tower, with the sanctuary open to the interior of the tower, and a low wall enclosing an entrance court.

There was no main deity, when it was found, in 2012 Lord Narasimha idol was kept and informal worship is being done.

Jainath Temple:

Where is it located? It is one of the ancient pilgrimage temple in Adilabad district.

When was it built? This is an important architectural monument of Pallava dynasty (4th to 9th century CE) in Telugu region. This is a small structure built on a platform which is 2 feet high. The temple is dedicated to Lord Lakshmi Narayana. The idol of the deity in the sanctum sanctorum is 6 feet tall in standing position and is made of black stone.

The temple has several stone inscriptions depicting the history of the temple along with slokas inscribed on it. Pallavas are famous for their rock-cut and structural temples (Mahabalipuram and Kanchi temples).

Bhadrakali Temple:

Where is it situated? It is situated on a hilltop between the two cities of Warangal and Hanamkonda.

When was the temple built?

The temple is believed to be built in 625 A.D by the King Pulakeshin II of Chalukyan dynasty to commemorate his victory over Vengi region of Andhra Desham, as per the writings on the temple wall.

Kakatiya kings later have adopted the temple and considered Goddess Bhadrakali as their "Kula Devatha". A lake was also built by Ganapati deva adjacent to the temple. Due to the fall of Kakatiya dynasty to the Muslim rulers of Delhi, the temple lost its prominence.

The exceptional feature of the temple is the 2.7 x 2.7 Sqm stone image of Goddess Bhadrakali with fierce looking eyes, and eight arms each carrying various weapons. Goddess Bhadrakali's vahana – Lion is placed opposite to the sanctum sanctorum. Temple also has Dwajasthambam and a Balipeetam.

Pushpagiri Temples:

Where is this located? It’s located in Kadapa District of Andhra Pradesh.

There are multiple legends associated with the origin of the temple complex. One of the legend says that it has come to existence from the Sathya Yuga when Garuda in the process of freeing his mother from slavery has inadvertently spilled a drop of ambrosia into the surrounding lake. Another legend claims that during the time of Treta Yuga, Lord Rama worshiped Lord Vaidyanatheswara here and the flowers used in the process have accumulated so high that a flowery mound is established and hence the name Pushpagiri.

Srisaila Khanda of Skand Purana praises this temple as 'Nirvritti Sangameswara' because of its reputation of devotees giving up lives in devotion to Lord Shiva.

Whatever is that the legend if is associated, it's currently wide acknowledged that the temple of Sri Vaidyanatheswara has been during this temple from a minimum of around 7th Century BCE.

The architectural styles of the Pushpagiri temple complex range from the age of Ikshvakus, Pallavas, Cholas, Chalukyas, Rastrakutas, Vaidumbas, Kayasthas and Vijayanagara empires.

Gudimallam Parameswara Temple:

Where is it located? It is located in Gudimallam village of Chittoor district, near to Thirupathi.

The Parasurameswara Temple contains a very early lingam with a full-length figure of Shiva, housed in the garbhagriha of the temple.

This is perhaps the second earliest lingam associated with Shiva discovered so far, and it has been dated to the 2nd/1st century BC or the 3rd century BC, or much later, to the 2nd century AD,3-4th century AD, or even, according to one source, as late as the 7th century AD. This is "the only sculpture of any importance" to survive from ancient South India before sculpture made under the Pallava Dynasty from the 7th century AD onwards, and "its mysteriousness lies in the total absence so far of any object in an even remotely similar manner within many hundreds of miles, and indeed anywhere in South India".

If assigned an early date, the figure on the lingam is ""one of the earliest surviving and unequivocal images of the god Shiva".

Undavalli Caves:

Where is it situated? Its is situated in Guntur District near Vijayawada.

This is a monolithic example of Indian rock-cut architecture and one of the finest testimonials to ancient viswakarma sthapathis.

These caves are said to be from 7th century. But one can see Gupta style of rock-cut Architecture which goes back to 4th-5th century CE. Most of emperor of Gupta's were Vaishnavas so we can see many sculpture of Narasimha, Lord Vishnu and Ramayans stories.

They are associated with the Vishnukundina kings of 420-620 CE. These caves are dedicated to Anantha Padmanabha and Lord Narashimha. Later Jain and Buddhist monks used these as rest houses.

It is an Impressive Four storey rock cut temple with East facing facade of 29m long, 16m wide. There are variation in depth of each floor. The ground floor is an unfinished low pillared hall with 8 pillars and 7 door openings on façade. The first storey accommodates triple shrine at back, each with the pillared hall in front, originally dedicated to the Trinity (Siva, Vishnu, and Brahma).

Sculptures on the walls represent Vaishnava deities. The second storey has a pillared rectangular shrine of Lord Vishnu on a serpent. Sculptures of Shiva and Vaishnava and a few like the Vaishnava Alwars are sculptured later on. The top floor was unfinished with a Triple Shrine. Some of the sculptural specimens are attributed to Chalukyan period. It has 5 meter long statue of Lord Buddha in reclining position.

Explorers, Heritage Enthusiasts must visit them.

How is electrical work installed when building a home with concrete walls?

Concealing of PVC conduits-

· Lay out and mark the path of your electrical conduit and electrical boxes as specified in the blueprints.

· Work shall be commenced after fixing of steel reinforcement on centering material.

· Conduits shall be firmly fixed on steel of RCC work by binding wire. This shall be done for every 4' along the conduit and try to tie it at the point the horizontal and vertical bars cross. Fixing of conduits shall be such that it will remain rigid during casting of slab, beam, and column even after use of vibrator.

Concealing of PVC conduits-

· Lay out and mark the path of your electrical conduit and electrical boxes as specified in the blueprints.

· Work shall be commenced after fixing of steel reinforcement on centering material.

· Conduits shall be firmly fixed on steel of RCC work by binding wire. This shall be done for every 4' along the conduit and try to tie it at the point the horizontal and vertical bars cross. Fixing of conduits shall be such that it will remain rigid during casting of slab, beam, and column even after use of vibrator.

· Make sure that you leave 12" of the conduit outside of the form so you can join it later to the rest of the buildings electrical supply.

· Deep junction boxes and other draw-in boxes shall be such that their open end and cantering material will not have gap in between so as to avoid concrete entering inside even after fixing covers to steel reinforcement; and be filled with dry sand.

· Open ends of conduits; to be concealed in walls, shall be provided with couplers / sockets at ends and be flush with bottom of beam, and located at the center of the beam.

· As far as possible bunching / grouping of conduits shall be avoided so that it will not affect strength of RCC work especially in beams.

· Suitable steel fish wire shall be drawn through in the conduits for drawing of wires later on.

Does Madurai meenakshi Amman temple have the eligibility to be a world wonder?

Ill straight away answer this question as yes . But I think we cant cent percent justify this statement because its not the same as it was built. It was rebuilt by a king of Madurai named Thirumalai Naikar, one of the greatest kings to be considered in history of Madurai who cared so much about the welfare of the people. He should also be remembered whenever we utter the name of the temple.

A sculpture of the great king.

HISTORY :

Ill straight away answer this question as yes . But I think we cant cent percent justify this statement because its not the same as it was built. It was rebuilt by a king of Madurai named Thirumalai Naikar, one of the greatest kings to be considered in history of Madurai who cared so much about the welfare of the people. He should also be remembered whenever we utter the name of the temple.

A sculpture of the great king.

HISTORY :

According to legend, the sacred Suyambulingam discovered by the king of Gods indira at Kadambavanam, was later enshrined by him in Madurai. The fact that the Lord is seen on the vehicle of Indira in this temple is said to be proof for this.

Many historical evidences of the temple have been found dating back from early A.D. The temple was almost completely destroyed in the year 1310 following the invasion of the Islamic conqueror Malikkapur kings who were followers of Islam were noted for their intolerance towards other religions, the invaders destroyed most of the ancient sculptures of the temple.

Thirugnanasambandar the Hindu Saint has mentioned the temple in his songs which go back to early 7th century. The Lord has been described as Alavai Iraivan in his songs.The temple was restored to its pristine glory in the late 14th century when the Hindu Kings came back to power in Madurai.This can also be termed as a new beginning of a new era in the history of the temple, when it was almost rebuilt.

HOLY TANK :

It was in this pond that the Golden Lotus for Indra to perform his pooja bloomed. This pond is also known as Adhi Theertham, Sivaganga and Uthama Theertham. This pond is situated within the temple complex. This theertham was created by Lord Sivaperuman by thrusting his Soolam (three ptonged spear) into the earth in deference to the plea of Nandhi Devar and other deities. It was here, that the plank of Sangam appeared and established greatness of the moral text called Thirukkural. It was here that Chockalingam was found by the grace of the Lord, by the first Guru of Dharmapura Adheenam and Saint Srilasri Guru Gnanasambandar. In keeping with the boons granted by the Lord to a stork, upto this date no fish nor other life is found in this miraculous sacred pond. Since this theertam was created before all other theerthams it is called Adhi Theertham and because it is much greater importance than all other theerthams, it is also called Parama Theertham as Gnana Theertham because it confers prosperity on all who bathe in it. As it grants heavenly abode it is also called Mukthi Theertham and as Sivaganga because the water from Ganga from the head of Lord Siva confluences with it and as Uthama Theertham because of its purity than any other theertham..

WARNING!!! Beautiful photos ahead:

Festival :

And this temple leads to one of the famous festivals attracting many foreigners to come and visit Madurai during the month of April, Chithirai Thiruvizha,

Chithirai Thiruvizha is an annual celebration celebrated during the month of April. It is celebrated during the Tamil month of CHITHIRAI. It is one of the longest celebrated festivals in the world and lasts for one month.

The first 15 days of the festival mark the celebrations of the coronation of Goddess Meenakshi.

and the Marriage of Lord Sundareswara and Goddess Meenakshi, and the next 15 days mark the celebrations of the Journey of Lord Azhagar from Kallazhagar temple in Alagar Koyil to Madurai. This festival attracts around 1 million people from different places of Tamil Nadu and also foreign tourists.

List of events

The following are the list of events in Chithirai festival.

Kodi Yetram

During this event the chief priest of Meenakshi temple will hoist the holy flag on the Dwajasthambam(Flag post) of the temple. This event declares the long event open. The flag will stay on the flag post until the end of the festival..

Pattabisekam

Pattabisekam is coronation ceremony. Meenakshi is crowned as the queen of Madurai on this day and she will rule the Pandya Kingdom for the next four months and after that her husband Lord Sunderaswarar will be crowned as the king of Madurai for the next eight months.

Meenakshi Thirukalyanam [My personal favorite]

Meenakshi Thirukalyanam is the great grand wedding celebration of Meenakshi amman and Lord shiva as Lord Sundereswarar in Madurai. Lord Sundereswarar coming to Madurai to marry Meenakshi is a grand wedding celebration. This tradition is still followed today.

Ther Thiruvizha

The day after Meenakshi Thirukalyanam is Ther Thiruvizha procession. The King and Queen of Pandya Kingdom Lord Sunderaswarar and Meenakshi come to see their subjects in a well decorated chariot. It attracts many people in the Masi streets of Madurai as viewers and it is an honor to help pull it.

Ethir Sevai

Part of the Chithirai Thiruvizha of Lord Kallazhagar temple at Alagar Koyil, the ‘Ethir Sevai' began on the fourth day of the festival. On this day, Alagar change his appearance as Kallar (Kallar vedam) when he travels via Kallar Nadu and enters Madurai city and the people of the city welcome him.

Alagar Vaigai Elenthuarulal

After the holy marriage of Meenakshi, her brother tries to come to the marriage. Lord Alagar comes from Alagarkoil to Madurai slowly and by making couple of stops on the way. It is considered that when reaching the Vaigai river bank, he hears that marriage is over, so he gets angry and returns to Alagarkoil after giving the gifts to Meenakshi and sundereswarar and this event happens in a mandapam in the middle of river Vaigai.

This defines the city’s tradition, history and culture for years. This festival and temple define Madurai and its history with the gods and kings ruled.

What are some lesser known facts about the Indian Gudimallam Shiva Temple?

Gudimallam is located on a diversion from the Tiruchanur Road, at a distance of about 31 km fl

Gudimallam is a small village in the Yerpedu mandal of the Chittoor district of Andhra Pradesh, India. It is located on a diversion from the Tiruchanur Road, at a distance of about 31 km from Tirupati and 18 km from Renigunta.

Among all the temples which surround Tirupati, the least known Gudimallam is also one of the most fascinating. Gudimallam, located just 30 km from the temple town, is one of the most ancient Shiva temples in India. The lingam here is believed to the longest continuously worshipped lingam in the world and is said to be over 2200 years old.

The temple is picturesquely located on the banks of the Swarnamukhi River, and the deity here is unique, a 1.35 M, seven-sided monolithic lingam. The front plane has the figure of Parasurama standing on the crouching figure of a Yaksha. It rests on a base of seven concentric rings, or peethams, only two of which are visible above the surface. The lingam is believed to be a manifestation of the trinity―Brahma at the bottom, Vishnu in the middle, and Shiva on top, and the story behind it is just as interesting.

Some of the copper coins obtained at Ujjain and belonging to the 3rd century BC contain figures which resemble the Linga of Gudimallam. A 1st-century sculpture in the Mathura Museum also contains a figure resembling the Gudimallam Shiva.

It is said that Parasurama, having killed his mother at the behest of his father, wanted to atone for his sin. A sage advised him to perform penance on the banks of the Swarnamukhi River, and he chose this sacred spot for the purpose. Each day, a lone flower would bloom in the river, which the sage would offer to the lord. Once Lord Brahma decided to test him, and arrived in the form of a dwarf, offering his help, to which Parasurama agreed. The dwarf aided him with his prayers but tried to find a way to test the sage. At last he hit upon an idea and plucked and threw off the single flower in the river before the sage could use it for his prayers. For the first few days, the sage thought that the flower had simply failed to bloom, but then he suspected his aide, lay in wait for him, and caught him in the act of plucking the flower. His anger aroused, he chased the dwarf, brandishing the axe. Brahma, realising that the joke had gone too far, called out to Shiva, who appeared and pacified Parasurama. He told him that his penance had borne fruit the minute Brahma had plucked the first flower from the river, and that he need not carry his guilt any longer. Further, he blessed them by merging them with the lingam, Brahma crouching down as the dwarf and Vishnu as Parasurama on his shoulders, holding his ax and a ram’s head. Such is the story of this unique temple!

There is an atmosphere of spirituality that pervades this temple, even in the absence of priests or devotees. After the crowd at Tirumala, a visit to this temple can be an uplifting spiritual experience!

What are the various features of Madurai Meenakshi Temple?
Originally Answered: What is the various features of Madurai Meenakshi Temple?

Ashta Shakthi Mandapam

A visitor who enters the temple through the eastern gateway, first enters this Mandapam(Hall). It was built by Thirumalai Nayakar's wives Rudrapathi Ammal and Tholimamai. In this hall food was once distributed to the devotees who came from far off places. The sculptures on the pillars here relate some of Lord Shiva's Thiruvilayadals (miracles) and also the story of Meenakshi's birth and her life as the princess of Madurai.

Meenakshi Nayakkar Mandapam

This big hall is adjacent to Ashta Shakthi Mandapam, consisting of 110 pillars carrying the figures of a peculiar animal with

Ashta Shakthi Mandapam

A visitor who enters the temple through the eastern gateway, first enters this Mandapam(Hall). It was built by Thirumalai Nayakar's wives Rudrapathi Ammal and Tholimamai. In this hall food was once distributed to the devotees who came from far off places. The sculptures on the pillars here relate some of Lord Shiva's Thiruvilayadals (miracles) and also the story of Meenakshi's birth and her life as the princess of Madurai.

Meenakshi Nayakkar Mandapam

This big hall is adjacent to Ashta Shakthi Mandapam, consisting of 110 pillars carrying the figures of a peculiar animal with a lion's body , and an elephant's head called Yalli.

Potramaraikulam (golden lotus tank)

This temple tank is an ancient tank where devotees take bath in the holy water. The area around this tank was the meeting place of the Tamil Sangam - the ancient academy of poets. The history of the sangam goes back to the days when gods dallied with men. This academy judged the worth of any work of literature presented before it by throwing it into the tank. Only those that did not sink were considered worthy of attention. The tank is surrounded by a pillared corridor. Steps lead down to the tank, enabling worshippers to take bathe in it.

Swami Sundareswarar Shrine

Lord Sundareswarar (Shiva) the consort of Goddess Meenakshi is to the north of Kilikoontu Mandapam. On your way you can worship a gigantic idol of Sri Ganesh called Mukkurini Pillaiyar. When the king Thirumalai Nayakar excavated a temple tank 3 km from Meenakshi temple he unearthed this idol of Vinayaka and erected the same here.
In the outer pragaram (corridor outside the main shrine) there is stump of the kadamba tree, which is said to be a part of the same tree under which Indra worshipped Shiva linga. Also in the outer corridor there are the Kadambathadi Mandapam and big hall called 'Velli Ambalam'. Here, An idol of Nataraja (Shiva as the Lord of Dance) is seen. This idol of Nataraja is covered with silver leaves. Hence this hall is named as Velli Ambalam (Silver Hall).

The Thousand Pillar Mandapam

It is the 'wonder of the place', Actually the number of pillars count to 985. Each pillar is sculptured and is a monument of the Dravidan sculpture. There is a Temple Art Museum in this 1000 pillars hall where you can see icons, photographs, drawings, etc., exhibiting the 1200 years old history. There are so many other smaller and bigger mandapams in the temple. Just outside this mandapam ,towards the west, are the Musical Pillars. Each pillar when stuck, Produces a different musical notes.

What is it about Madurai Meenakshi Amman Temple? Does it really stand out as unique comparing to Tanjore Temple? Do you know the entire history?
Originally Answered: What is it about Madurai Meenakshi Amman Temple? Does it really stand out unique comparing to Tanjore temple? Do you know the entire history?

It is dedicated to Parvati, known as Meenakshi, and her consort, Shiva, here namedSundareswarar.

The temple now we worship was not the one built by the ancient people when Meenakshi Amman actually lived. It was rebuilt by Thirumalai Naikar, one of the greatest kings to be considered in history of Madurai who cared so much about the welfare of the people. He should also be remembered whenever we utter the temple’s name. Thats why I am putting this in the first place.

According to legend, the sacred Suyambulingam discovered by the king of Gods indira at Kadambavanam, was later enshrined b

It is dedicated to Parvati, known as Meenakshi, and her consort, Shiva, here namedSundareswarar.

The temple now we worship was not the one built by the ancient people when Meenakshi Amman actually lived. It was rebuilt by Thirumalai Naikar, one of the greatest kings to be considered in history of Madurai who cared so much about the welfare of the people. He should also be remembered whenever we utter the temple’s name. Thats why I am putting this in the first place.

HISTORY :

According to legend, the sacred Suyambulingam discovered by the king of Gods indira at Kadambavanam, was later enshrined by him in Madurai. The fact that the Lord is seen on the vehicle of Indira in this temple is said to be proof for this.

Many historical evidences of the temple have been found dating back from early A.D. The temple was almost completely destroyed in the year 1310 following the invasion of the Islamic conqueror Malikkapur kings who were followers of Islam were noted for their intolerance towards other religions, the invaders destroyed most of the ancient sculptures of the temple.

Thirugnanasambandar the Hindu Saint has mentioned the temple in his songs which go back to early 7th century. The Lord has been described as Alavai Iraivan in his songs.The temple was restored to its pristine glory in the late 14th century when the Hindu Kings came back to power in Madurai.This can also be termed as a new beginning of a new era in the history of the temple, when it was almost rebuilt.

PAINTINGS :

The drawings depicting incidents of the Thiruvilayadal or miraculous dramas of Lord Shiva belong to the Naicker period. There are paintings depicting the 64 miracles of Lord Shiva, all which were enacted in Madurai. These aesthetic drawings can be seen on the northern wall facing the Pottamarai kulam of tank of the golden lotus. These drawings are at present being given a facelift by using natural dyes at a cost of Rs 26.25 lakhs.

A beautiful painting in the temple :

HOLY TANK :

It was in this pond that the Golden Lotus for Indra to perform his pooja bloomed. This pond is also known as Adhi Theertham, Sivaganga and Uthama Theertham. This pond is situated within the temple complex. This theertham was created by Lord Sivaperuman by thrusting his Soolam (three ptonged spear) into the earth in deference to the plea of Nandhi Devar and other deities. It was here, that the plank of Sangam appeared and established greatness of the moral text called Thirukkural. It was here that Chockalingam was found by the grace of the Lord, by the first Guru of Dharmapura Adheenam and Saint Srilasri Guru Gnanasambandar. In keeping with the boons granted by the Lord to a stork, upto this date no fish nor other life is found in this miraculous sacred pond. Since this theertam was created before all other theerthams it is called Adhi Theertham and because it is much greater importance than all other theerthams, it is also called Parama Theertham as Gnana Theertham because it confers prosperity on all who bathe in it. As it grants heavenly abode it is also called Mukthi Theertham and as Sivaganga because the water from Ganga from the head of Lord Siva confluences with it and as Uthama Theertham because of its purity than any other theertham..

Every temple is unique in its own way the temple forms the heart and lifeline of the 2,500-year-old city of Madurai. It is said that the temple was originally built in the 6th century BC by survivors of the Kumari Kandam.

Is it mentioned in any Ramayana that Sri ram installed a Shiva linga?

Jai SiyaRam!

Yes, It’s there in the Sri Ramcharitmanas.

“This is a most delightful and excellent spot; its glory is immeasurable and cannot be described in words. I will install (an emblem of) Lord Sambhu here: it is the crowning ambition of My heart. Hearing this the lord of the monkeys despatched a number of messengers, who invited and fetched all the great sages. Having installed an emblem of Lord Siva and worshipped It with due solemnity, He said, No one else is so dear to Me as Siva. An enemy of Siva although he calls himself a devotee of Mine, cannot attain to Me even in a dream. He who is opposed to Sankara and yet aspires for devotion to Me, is doomed to perdition, stupid and dull-witted as he is.”

(source : Sri Ramcharitmanas, lanka Kanda)

In valmiki Ramayana though, No such thing is there, and the verse 6.123.19, Is Translated wrongly As Lord Shiva, instead of the Sea God and has been removed by the Critical edition all together. The event can also be found in the skanda puran and Shiv Puran.

What is the significance of placing Shadari (a crown like object) on ones head in Vaishnavaite temples?

I am not a vaishnavite, but me being a curious kid, I once asked a priest in a temple regarding the significance of the same and his reply was:

I am not a vaishnavite, but me being a curious kid, I once asked a priest in a temple regarding the significance of the same and his reply was:

“The vaishnavam was flourished and developed mostly by the azhwaars(Alwars), one of the most decorated alwars is “Nammazhwaar” who’s real name is “Sadagopan”. He lived in Thirukarugavoor, a place nere Thiruvaroor during 43rd year of Kali i.e., 2nd Millenium BCE (Around 3059 BCE). He spent his life under a tamarind tree by writing so many poems about the various forms of Thirumaal(Vishnu) from the 108 Divya Desams(108 sacred shrines of Vishnu).

In that collection, in one of the poem, He says the following verses to the Uppiliappan of Uppiliappan Temple - Wikipedia ,

“I, Sadagopan of Kurugur [am] one who is ... joined with His Holy Feet that grew to the heavens." (I forgot the exact Tamil verses, will update once I get it)

The "grew to the heavens" part is about Vishnu's incarnation as Vamana the dwarf, but what's important for our purposes is that Nammalwar said that he was one with Vishnu's lotus feet.

So Sri Vaishnavas started using a crown, called the Sadagopam, to represent the head of Nammalwar (since his name was Sadagopan), and on the top of the Sadagopam are the footprints of Vishnu, as you can see in the image above. The idea is that just as Nammalwar surrendered to the lotus feet of Vishnu, so should you. That is the origin of placing the Sadagopam on people's heads in Sri Vaishnava temples.

Another version is, the Nammazhwaar is considered as the head of all the azhwaars and other azhwaars including ourselves are the limbs and other parts of the body.

The "Sataari" placed on the heads of all the devotees in Vishnu temples is supposed to be Nammalwar himself. All other Alwars are his limbs as brought out in the following invocatory verse:

“Bhootam Saraschya, mahadaavya Bhattanatha
Sri Bhakti sara kulashekhara yogi vahaan
Bhakataangri-renu parakala yateendra mishran,
Srimath paraangusa munim pranatosmi Nityam."

Source: Alwars, Nammalwar, ThirukKurugoor, Alwar Thirunagari, Temples, Sri Rangam, Sataari, Sadagopan, Sadari

Nammazhwar was glorified and decorated by every vaishnavite and his works are still being sung in all the vishnu temples.

References: History of Classical Sanskrit Literature

Cheers :)

Is Aaseevagam (ancient Tamil religion) the root religion of all the world religions? Yazidanism, Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism are all proven to originate from Tamil words and Tamil mythology of Aasevagam.

Let us get this straight first. The original religion of Tamils is NO RELIGION. That is why I am fascinated with my ancestors and I truly admire them. I admire them because they did not get mired in the cesspool called organised/institutionalized religion. Even the ancient Greeks and Romans got lost in the Daedalian labyrinth called organized religion. My people had enough sense to stay away from it. Just a sacrifice here, a ritual dance there and then they got on with their daily business.

Now let us turn to Aseevagam aka Ajivikas. Nowadays I do not trust Indian authorship on anything related to religion and it includes Sanskrit and Tamil extremists. A.L. Basham has written an excellent book on this called “History and Doctrines of the Ajivikas - A vanished Indian religion” and what is more important is it is a dispassionate neutral view.

  • Based on scholarship, Basham dates the founder of Ajivika sect, Makkali Gosala, to roughly around 500 BCE.
  • The founder was a contemporary of Mahavira and this entire sect appears to be a reaction to all other existing religions.
  • If we tie up the dating of Keezhadi and the fact Gosala was born later, we can logically conclude Aaseevagam has nothing to do with Tamil region.
  • Ajivikas mostly practiced vegetarianism and that hardly looks like anything Tamils could have come up with considering our liking for meat.
  • All references, mostly passing references, to Ajivikas in Southern region are mentioned only in later Sangam text like Manimekalai. Logically speaking Sangam literature should have been talking a lot about this if we indeed had a religious practice that we invented.
  • Epigraphical evidence about Ajivikas in Tamil Nadu only start from 446 CE.
  • Ajivikas believed in rebirth which of course is completely opposite to hero worship style of my ancestors.
  • Absolute determinism of Ajivika school is completely in contradiction to the concept of free will that is celebrated by Thiruvalluvar. They are like water and oil. Simple as that.
  • While it cannot denied that we adopted some Ajivika practices and this sect lasted much longer in Tamil region than elsewhere, it is evident that this religious philosophy was not something founded by Tamils.

When we did not have organized religion, we were writing fun stuff like lovers embracing each other like red soil that gets dissolved in rain water. I will take that any day over any text that tells me that I should not look at girls.

What's so special about Madurai?

Here are four things.

Gandhi the Fakir

It was Madurai, where Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi decided to renounce the personal use of upper garment and transform into a loincloth wearing fakir. The date was September 21, 1921

[1]
.

Today, one can visit the famous Gandhi Museum (Former palace of Rani Mangammal ) in Madurai, which among other things houses the blood stained clothes worn by Mahatma Gandhi on the day of his assassination

[2]
, and a letter
[3]
written by Gandhi to some crazy guy in Berlin asking him not to fight and all - the guy never responded.

Ancient Madurai

Madurai is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities of India

[4]
. It finds mention in both Ramayana
[5]
by Valmiki and Arthashashtra by Kautilya
[6]
and the works of both Pliny the Younger and Ptolemy. The famous Moroccan explorer Ibn Battuta got married here
[7]
.

The Sangam era urban settlement of Keezhadi was excavated a mere 12 Kms from Madurai, along the banks of the Vaigai River - There are some uncanny similarities between Keezhadi and the much older Indus Valley Civilization. Experts date the site at around 200–300 BCE. It is a new found evidence of a thriving and advanced ancient civilization on the banks of the Vaigai River

[8]
.

The Temple

Madurai is also synonymous with the really awesome Meenakshi Amman Temple - perhaps one of the greatest architectural wonders of the world, dedicated to the now almost extinct matrilinial traditions in Southern India, the Feminine Power

[9]
, the worship of an all loving, compassionate and genteel female goddess - the one with beautifully shaped eyes like a fish - Meenakshi.

According to the legends, she was a Pandya Princess of Madurai, who inherited the kingdom from her father and went all the way to modern day Kailash Mountain on a conquest, defeating all the kings who came in her way - finally meeting her match in a good looking hermit by the name Sundareshwara who turned out to be Shiva himself. They got married in the month of Chitirai

[10]
in a ceremony where Vishnu himself performed the duties of her brother, as seen in the image below
[11]
.

Remember, it was she who chose her husband. It was she who was the alpha.

Binte-Dil in Madurai

In 1311 CE, The same Meenakshi Amman temple dedicated to the feminine power was plundered and destroyed by a Born-Hindu Eunuch from Khambhat in modern day Gujarat

[12]
.

As per records, this Eunuch was bought for his physical beauty and wit by Nusrat Khan, the General of Alauddin Khilji for 1000 Dinars (allegedly)

[13]
- making him famous as a Hazar Dinari (the highest title possible for a slave)
[14]
.

He was converted to Islam

[15]
and owing to his strategic deftness - eventually made a general by Khilji. Some also hold him responsible for ultimately assassinating Khilji himself.

Thanks to a recent Bollywood movie - you might remember him as Malik Kafur.

One more thingie.

There is a stinking drain, just north of the modern day Madurai Railway Station - if you ask the locals, they’d tell you, it is actually the now almost dead Vaigai River.

According to Matasya Purana, This is the exact place

[16]
[17]
[18]
, where the first of the 9 realized avatars of Vishnu appeared. The avatar was in the form of a large fish during the great deluge - The Matsya Avatar (Note: Scriptures of every major culture in the world mentions a flood of ‘biblical’ proportions, a la… Noah’s ark story - this is our Indian version, which took place in modern day Madurai).

Thank you for reading. Cheers and peace.

Does Rama meet Sita in Valmiki Ramayana?

Yes, In Valmiki Ramayana, Rama and Sita meet first time on Swayamvara (wedding day) and then later after the abduction of Sita by Ravan during exile. Rama found out Sita's whereabouts by help of Hanumana then Rama wage war against Ravan and rescued sita. So, Rama and Sita reunite after Ravana's death (Ravan Haran). But, lord Rama asked Sita to proved her virtue (chasity) only then she allowed to enter palace that's why Sita walk on fire that time mother earth evoked and took her in womb.

Which is the oldest Shiva temple?

The history of India is very old and so is the history of Sanatana Dharma, with which temples are associated.

The construction of temples started somewhere around 2000 years ago.

So, the question of finding an answer to the oldest Shiva temple is bit difficult. Each temple that is considered as oldest is questioned by another set of people claiming their temple is the oldest one.

  • Somnath temple was constructed by Moon himself, so it may be the oldest and is the first Jyothirlinga among the 12 Jyothirlingas. It was destroyed many times by invaders and reconstructed again.
  • According to sources Mundeshwari temple is the oldest temple in India, which is located in Kaimur district of Bihar.
    • Archaeologists believe that the temple was constructed in 108 AD.
    • The temple is dedicated to Shiva and Shakthi.

Who built Sri Meenakshi Amman Temple at Madurai? How was it built with such grandeur by the king's own resources then?

1.The temple is very old.

2.Sanctum and the ancient temple was built by Pandya Kings- one of the longest ruling dynasty of the world.

What is the history of Porpadiyan in the Madurai Meenakshi Temple?

Actually saying Porkai Pandiayan is shortly referred as porpandyan and his history is as follows.

பொற்கை பாண்டியன்

Porkai Pandyan is a Pandya King who ruled the Pandya country in between 100-120 B.C. Within Pandya kings he’s the chief in never unerring justice.

It was time when Madurai was Naanmadak kuudal city. In nights, the king in might of guarding come across the streets and one midnight when he was on his guarding process, he heard a speech from a home. When pandyan listen carefully, one Vedhiyan was talking with his wife. That he was going overseas as business and thus his wife answering that there is a fear about thieves and she is frighten about it. Our king’s scepter will guard you and you needn’t to fear, told the vedhiyan and goes off.

Listening to this conversation, the king Pandiya’s mind filled in joy and he wondered thinking about his people’s credit on him. He also guarded that street everyday without fail and one night he heard a speech sound from the Vedhiyan home and the uncertainty king knocked the door. Then, the king who thought that vedhian might suspicion his wife if he know I have came, knocked everyone door on the street.

The next day, the people of the street appealed in the king’s court. There were ministers, poets and many other leaders presented. The thief who knocked our doors should get cut off his hand, said the people. The king asked to get a sword and cut off his hand! To those wonder, the king’s statement as himself knocking the door stunned everyone those heard.

The Pandyan who hold a golden hand then, got the name Porkai (golden hand) Pandyan.

Why do Hindu temples in Tamil Nadu alone look so majestic, when compared to Northern, Western and Eastern States of India?

Whole India was having several excellent temples everywhere but unfortunately north was heavily attacked by several evil, stupid aliens who were large scale desert robbers did not have even basic senses to sense the beauty of those excellent monuments, which went on evil rampage of destroying every possible temples.

Fortunately, the south were far on other extreme end with lesser threat, ruled by mighty Cholas, Cheras and Pandiya kingdoms and was able to retain most of the temples though still few bigger temples have the remnants of damages done by such evil, stupid demons during later periods

Whole India was having several excellent temples everywhere but unfortunately north was heavily attacked by several evil, stupid aliens who were large scale desert robbers did not have even basic senses to sense the beauty of those excellent monuments, which went on evil rampage of destroying every possible temples.

Fortunately, the south were far on other extreme end with lesser threat, ruled by mighty Cholas, Cheras and Pandiya kingdoms and was able to retain most of the temples though still few bigger temples have the remnants of damages done by such evil, stupid demons during later periods of evil, stupid alien invasions.

Is it possible to write Sanskrit with the Tamil alphabet?

No. Tamil scripts are tailor made for the Tamil language. It has the minimum number of letters among ALL Indian languages! This simplicity gives it a lot of advantages such as higher literacy rates, ease of making a type writer, ease of printing etc.

In the Tamil country, the Granta scripts are used to write Sanskrit.

Later addition: Tamil is the only Indian language that could be written using ASCII art during the pre-GUI USENET era.

Why did Lord Rama seek help from Sugriva when he was living in exile in Kishkindha?

After Devi Sita was abducted, Sri Rama had following options -

  • Return Ayodhya and seek help from Bharata
  • Seek help from king Janaka (Devi Sita's father)
  • Seek help from Kishkindha king Vali
  • Find Devi Sita and punish her abductor through his own courage, bravery and valour

He didn't took first two alternatives because by doing so, he would have broken his words given to his father that he will spend fourteen years in exile. He didn't approached Vali because he had wronged his younger brother Sugriva.

He exercised the last option by befriending Sugriva. Sri Rama had lost everything at this point - his

After Devi Sita was abducted, Sri Rama had following options -

  • Return Ayodhya and seek help from Bharata
  • Seek help from king Janaka (Devi Sita's father)
  • Seek help from Kishkindha king Vali
  • Find Devi Sita and punish her abductor through his own courage, bravery and valour

He didn't took first two alternatives because by doing so, he would have broken his words given to his father that he will spend fourteen years in exile. He didn't approached Vali because he had wronged his younger brother Sugriva.

He exercised the last option by befriending Sugriva. Sri Rama had lost everything at this point - his kingdom, his father, a well-wisher Jatayu and his beloved wife Devi Sita.

Neither he nor Sugriva had any resources which would have helped him to find his wife and fight Ravana. But he showed us that by following the path of Dharma, everything can be achieved.

Sri Rama made Sugriva the king by slaying Vali. Hanumanji went to Lanka and gathered information about Devi Sita. Further challenge was to cross the mighty ocean. It was also overcome. Subsequently, Ravana got killed and Sri Rama was finally reunited with Devi Sita.

He got lifelong friends in the form of Sugriva and Vibhishana. He got Hanumanji as his devotee. The evil king Ravana was killed alongwith his well wishers. The purpose of his incarnation was fulfilled. And most important thing - the upcoming generation got a message that only by treading the path of Dharma, one can overcome any challenge in life.

What are some of the amazing facts about Meenakshi Amman Temple?

INTRODUCTION:

Meenakshi Amman Temple is one of the oldest and most important temples in India. Located in Madurai, the temple has a great mythological and historical significance.

HISTORY:

Renowned for its astonishing architecture, Meenakshi Temple was nominated as one of the wonders of the world.

The history of Meenakshi Temple dates back to the 1st century C.E with scholars claiming it to be as old as the city itself. It is said that Kulashekarar Pandyan, who built the temple as per the instructions given in his dream by Lord Shiva.

UNSUNG FACTS:

The temple as it stands today, however, was rebuilt throughout the 16th century as it was destroyed by the Muslim invaders.

The temple has 14 gopurams and 33,000 sculptures including two golden sculptured vimanas that is the tower above the sanctum.

ARCHITECTURE:

The southern gopuram is the tallest of them all with a height of 170 feet. The most popular fact about the temple is that it is home to a hall that has a 1000s pillars, a sacred pool with a golden lotus, innumerable small shrines, gardens, and elephant sheds.

TOURISM:

Friday sees the most number of devotees visit the temple with the number going as high as 25,000. Meenakshi Temple also hosts an annual festival called Meenakshi Thirukalayanam that is held in April. About 1 million devotees visit temple during this festival.

What is the history of Madurai?

Madurai, in the past (until 1949) Madura, city, south-central Tamil Nadu state, southern India. It is situated on the Vaigai River, about 30 miles (48 km) southeast of Dindigul. Madurai is the third most populous, and probably the oldest, city in the state.

Madurai is one of the oldest cities of India, with a history dating all the way back to the Sangam period of the pre Christian era. The glory of Madurai returned in a diminished form in the earlier part of this millennium; it later on came under the rule of the Vijayanagar kingdom after its ransack by the ravaging armies of Delhi (Malik Kafu

Madurai, in the past (until 1949) Madura, city, south-central Tamil Nadu state, southern India. It is situated on the Vaigai River, about 30 miles (48 km) southeast of Dindigul. Madurai is the third most populous, and probably the oldest, city in the state.

Madurai is one of the oldest cities of India, with a history dating all the way back to the Sangam period of the pre Christian era. The glory of Madurai returned in a diminished form in the earlier part of this millennium; it later on came under the rule of the Vijayanagar kingdom after its ransack by the ravaging armies of Delhi (Malik Kafur). During the 16th and 18th centuries, Madurai was ruled by the Nayak Emperors, the foremost of whom was Tirumalai Nayakar. The Sangam period poet Nakkeerar is associated with some of the Tiruvilayadal episodes of Sundareswarar - that are enacted as a part of temple festival traditions even today.

The Sangam age or the Golden age of Tamil literature – produced masterpieces way back in the Pre Christian era and in early 1st millennium . Madurai was the seat of the Tamil Sangam or Academy of learning.

The whole city of Madurai, is built around the Meenakshi Sundareswarar Temple – the temple par excellence. Concentric rectangular lanes surround the temple, symbolizing the structure of the universe.

The Cholas ruled Madurai from 920 AD till the beginning of the 13th century. In 1223 AD Pandyas regained their kingdom and once again become prosperous. Pandian Kings patronised Tamil language in a great way. During their period, many master-pieces were created. "Silapathikaram", the great epic in Tamil was written based on the story of Kannagi who burnt Madurai as a result of the injustice caused to her husband Kovalan. In April 1311, Malik Kafur, the general of Alauddin Khilji who was then the ruler of Delhi, reached Madurai and raided and robbed the city for precious stones, jewels, and other rare treasures. This led to the subsequent raids by other Muslim Sultans. In 1323, the Pandya kingdom including Madurai became a province of the Delhi empire, under the Tughlaks.

The 1371, the Vijayanagar dynasty of Hampi captured Madurai and it became part of the Vijayanagar empire. Kings of this dynasty were in habit of leaving the captured land to governors called Nayaks. This was done for the efficient management of their empire. The Nayaks paid fixed amount annually to the Vijayanagar empire. After the death of Krishna Deva Raya (King of Vijayanagar empire) in 1530 AD, the Nayaks became independent and ruled the territories under their control. Among Nayaks, Thirumalai Nayak (1623-1659) was very popular, even now he is popular among people, since, it was he who contributed to the creation of many magnificent structures in and around Madurai. The Raja Gopuram of the Meenakshi Amman Temple, The Pudu Mandapam and The Thirumalai Nayakar's Palace are living monuments to his artistic fervor.

Thirumalai Nayakar Mahal

  • Madurai began slipping under the control of the British's East India Company. In 1781, British selected their delegates to take care of Madurai. George Procter was the primary authority of Madurai.

Presently after India's freedom, Madurai is one of the significant locale of Tamilnadu State. Later on Madurai region was bifurcated into two locale in particular Madurai and Dindugul Districts. In Madurai District, there are 15 State Assembly supporters and two parliament voting demographics.

The history of Madurai will not be complete without mentioning the name of Rani Mangammal, the woman of great skill and sagacity. History does not provide many instances of ruling queens in Tamil Nadu. Though it was considered that women were not suited to succeed the throne of a kingdom, Rani Mangammmal, however shines in almost solitary eminence as an able and powerful ruler in Tamil Nadu.

Madurai is acclaimed for its temples.The Aappudaiyaar Koyil Tevara Stalam and the Koodalazhagar Divya Desam are the most significant sanctuaries one ought to infrequently miss to go. In the region of Madurai is Tirupparamkunram, one of the 6 padai veedu holy places of Murugan (celebrated in Madurai Sangam Nakeerar's Tirumurugaatruppadai). Additionally in the region of Madurai is Alagar Koyil, one of the conspicuous Divya Desam holy places of the Sri Vaishnavite confidence.

What’s the real history of Sabarimala?

Lord Ayyappa was a brave prince, he was also known to be the syncretic (born out of non sexual means) son of Lord Shiva and Mohini (female form of Lord Vishnu).

As per the legend, Lord Ayyappa once set out to kill a demon that resided in the hills Patthanamthitta (present day Sabrimala). However, as soon as he killed the demon, a beautiful princess emerged out of the caracass and asked Lord Ayyappa to marry her. Lord Ayyappa had already vowed to serve his disciples by then and hence politely diclined.

The princess was heartbroken, she begged to the Lord to change his mind. So, Lord Ayyappa promised her that the day the kanni swamis (first time visitors) stopped coming to the temple, he will marry her. Till then he would vouch Naishthik Bhramacharya (eternal brahmacharya).

The princess also vouched that she would wait for Lord Ayyappa to come looking for her and so she went and sat on a nearby hillock. Even today, you will find the temple of Malikapurathamma on the way to Sabrimala.

Back then, all the women CHOSE to not enter the Sabrimala temple as a solidarity to Malikapurathamma, which over the years got twisted into women are not allowed to enter, which was not the case originally

Hope this helps.

How old is the Rameshwaram Temple?

The temple in its current shape is believed to have been built during the 17th century, while Fergusson believes the small vimana in the west corridor belongs to the 11th or 12th centuries.

The temple is said to have been sanctioned for construction by King Kizhavan Sethupathi or Raghunatha Kilavan. The contribution of the Jaffna kings of the Sethupathy dynasty to the temple was considerable.[6] King Jeyaveera Cinkaiariyan (1380 — 1410 CE) shipped stone blocks from Koneswaram temple, Trincomalee to renovate the temple's sanctum sanctorum. Jeyaveera Cinkaiariyan's successor Gunaveera Cinkaiariya

The temple in its current shape is believed to have been built during the 17th century, while Fergusson believes the small vimana in the west corridor belongs to the 11th or 12th centuries.

The temple is said to have been sanctioned for construction by King Kizhavan Sethupathi or Raghunatha Kilavan. The contribution of the Jaffna kings of the Sethupathy dynasty to the temple was considerable.[6] King Jeyaveera Cinkaiariyan (1380 — 1410 CE) shipped stone blocks from Koneswaram temple, Trincomalee to renovate the temple's sanctum sanctorum. Jeyaveera Cinkaiariyan's successor Gunaveera Cinkaiariyan (Pararacacekaran V), a trustee at Rameswaram who also oversaw structural development of this temple and the promotion of Saivite beliefs donated part of his revenue to Koneswaram.

Especially to be remembered are the immense sums that were spent during the tenure of Pradani Muthirulappa Pillai towards the restoration of the Pagodas which were falling into ruins and the splendid Chockattan Mantapam or the cloistered precincts of the temple at Rameswaram that he finally completed. The rulers of Sri Lanka also contributed to the temple - Parakrama Bahu (1153-1186 CE) was involved in the construction of the sanctum sanctorum of the temple.

Can the character of Lord Rama in Ramayana by Maharshi Valmiki be considered as a hero or Purushottam at all?

Lord Rama is maryada Purushoththama.

Lord Rama is an ideal hero.

Maryadaa purusha ——— a person who never cross the rules and regulations on earth with his best qualities. Maryadaa Purushoththama is the only one among the best persons. He is noblest of noble,greatest of great people. Rama is having Anantha kalyana guna. I.e., having infinitive great virtues. As we can't count the drops in ocean, in the same way, we can't analyse his great values.

Heroism is one among those qualities.

Once Valmiki asked Narada that who was the human being in that period, having the best qualities on the earth. He searched for sixteen qualities in one human. He said he was liking to hear about such person with the most enthusiasm. He said also that Narada was only capable of giving such information about a human as he was thrilokagna (having all knowledge about the three worlds). Those questions are as follows:

Kon vasmin saamprathaam loke gunavaan kascha veeryavaan,

Dharmagnascha kruthagnascha satyavakyo dhrud.havrathaha || 2.

Chaarithrena cha ko yukthaha sarvabhutheshu ko hithaha,

Vidwaan kah kassamardhascha kaschiika priyadarśanaha ||. 3.

Aathmavaan ko jithakrodho dyuthimaan konasuuyakaha,

Kasya bibhyathi devaascha jaatharoshascha samyuge ||. 4.

The person having the most high qualities, the one with great courage and valour, Dharmagnascha—— having knowledge of all dharma, Kruthagna ——- who reminds good deeds of others , the truthful person, strong minded, noble character, doing only good to all worldly people, the great scholar, highly talented in all duties and responsibilities,always giving pleasure to the people,with his good structural qualities (sadïka priyadarsanaha —- beyond description), aathmavaan —- the one with great self control, winning wrath, having enlightenment, out of jealousy and without envy, if get angry even all Gods would fear.

Narada said that it was very difficult having such qualities on the earth as Valmi pointed. After taking some time, he spelled about Ishwaaku vamsa prabhavaha Ramaha. Rama was only that one.

Read again for his qualities from eight to eighteen slokas in the first Sarga of Balakanda of Ramayana.

Valmiki was Brahmana by birth, and not Kshatriya. He was born in the ancestry of Prachethasa. He entered into tribal caste by his bad deeds. He was purified by looks of Saptharshis, and practiced the vyatchastha of Ramanama. After one thousand yugas he got the name Valmiki as he told himself. It is evident in Adhyathma Ramayana, Brahmanda Purana written by Vedavyasa Maharshi.

What is the story of Ravana’s telling Shiva to reside in his bhavan?

Ravan was a great devotee of lord Shiv. Once he did great penance to please lord Shiv. Shiv became pleased with him and asked Ravan to ask for a boon.

Ravan asked lord Shiv to reside with him in Lanka so that Lanka becomes inconquerable by anyone. As Lord Shiv is considered to be avadhardani… he granted him his wish.

Lord Shiv gave Ravan a shivling and told him that wherever you keep this shivling, that place will not be conquered by anyone else.

But Ravan could not keep this shivling on the ground till he reached Lanka……or else the place where he would keep it would be inconquerable.

Meanwhile In

Ravan was a great devotee of lord Shiv. Once he did great penance to please lord Shiv. Shiv became pleased with him and asked Ravan to ask for a boon.

Ravan asked lord Shiv to reside with him in Lanka so that Lanka becomes inconquerable by anyone. As Lord Shiv is considered to be avadhardani… he granted him his wish.

Lord Shiv gave Ravan a shivling and told him that wherever you keep this shivling, that place will not be conquered by anyone else.

But Ravan could not keep this shivling on the ground till he reached Lanka……or else the place where he would keep it would be inconquerable.

Meanwhile Indra, the king of God's came to know about this boon given to Ravan. He got scared and and ganpati bappa, the vigna harata to stop the shivling from reaching Lanka. He was scared that Ravan would soon conquer the heavens as he was very powerful.

Ganpati bappa agreed to help him and in the evening, when it was time for Ravan’s prayers, ganpati bappa appears in the form of a young boy in front of Ravan. Ravan asks the child to hold the shivling for some time till he could offer his evening prayer. The child(ganpati bappa) agreed to it. And when Ravan was offering his prayers ganpati bappa kept the shivling down on the ground.

When Ravan returned,he was very angry and asked the boy why did he keep the shivling on the ground, the boy replied that it was very heavy and that he could not carry it for such a long time…and thus Ravan lost the opportunity to keep lord Shiv (in the form of shivling) in Lanka forever
